awd_titl_txt: Fundamental Study of Low-Cycle-Fatigue Behavior of High-Entropy Alloys
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract

This project will study  low-cycle-fatigue  behavior of  a new class of multi-component alloys called high-entropy alloys. These alloys have attracted huge attention in recent five years for their unique mechanical properties. The transformative potential of the present work is represented as a systematic and innovative investigation for structural characterization experiments, thus revealing the deformation mechanisms under cyclic loading and integrating the design, fabrication, verification, improvement, and prediction components, which can be applied for the studies of other advanced materials in the future.  Students and researchers involved in this project will have opportunities to experience the state-of-the-art research equipment at the national laboratories. The outreach activities will include the K-12 science education, minority involvement, and efforts to engage the public. The results of the project will be disseminated through avenues accessible to the scientific community and to the general public with an emphasis on middle- and high-school students, as well as women and minority students. Appropriate aspects of the research results will be incorporated into the principal investigator's (PI's) graduate and undergraduate course materials to introduce students to modern interdisciplinary materials research.  

Technical Abstract

The goal of this project is to (1) study the low-cycle fatigue (LCF) behavior of high-entropy alloys (HEAs) by varying the structures (e.g., controlling the Al content), (2) clarify the deformation mechanisms of HEAs during LCF using state-of-art characterization methods (e.g., advanced microscopy and in-situ neutron diffraction), and (3) based on the fundamental understanding of the deformation behavior obtained from the present work, design and develop innovative HEAs with excellent LCF properties. HEAs attract huge attention in recent five years for their unique and excellent mechanical properties. Even though extensive studies have been devoted to the mechanical behavior,most of these research activities are for monotonic tests and almost none has focused on the fatigue properties, especially LCF. The mechanism of fatigue behavior must be examined carefully before HEAs can indeed be introduced in practical applications. The critical issues, thus, become obvious: (1) how do the multi-principal elements affect structures, and further, fatigue properties; (2) how does the high-entropy configuration influence the deformation mechanism; and (3) if the above two aspects have positive effects on the fatigue resistance, what are the fundamental contributing factors. Accordingly, a hypothesis is proposed and to be tested in the present work that HEAs with some specific compositions (i.e., structures) will show superior fatigue resistance over traditional alloys due to (1) great tendency to form twins, (2) solute atoms and large distortion from the element-size mismatch to pin dislocations, and (3) the interaction between dislocation and twinning, before fatigue-crack initiation and during crack propagation at room and elevated temperatures, and their long-term performance can be modulated and further improved by cold or hot treatment (e.g., cold rolling to control grain size). It is expected that the mechanism of LCF behavior could be revealed by a combination of the proposed experimental, theoretical, and modeling efforts, thus providing the fundamental understanding of the deformation behavior for single- and multiple-phase HEAs.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report: Fundamental Study of Low-Cycle-Fatigue Behavior of High-Entropy Alloys

Our project explored the low-cycle-fatigue (LCF) behavior of high-entropy alloys (HEAs), a unique class of materials with equal or near-equal proportions of multiple elements. Unlike traditional alloys that rely on one primary element, HEAs are designed with multiple principal elements, providing exceptional strength, toughness, and resistance to extreme conditions. By investigating HEAs, we aim to advance materials science in fields ranging from aerospace and automotive to energy, where materials are constantly exposed to repeated stress and fatigue.

Intellectual Merit

The study of HEAs is at the cutting edge of materials research, holding the potential to overcome many of the limitations of traditional alloys. One critical challenge in materials design is to understand how materials behave under cyclic-stresses conditions where they experience repeated stretching and compression. This project focused specifically on the low-cycle-fatigue (LCF) behavior of HEAs, which refers to how these materials respond to intense stresses over a limited number of cycles. By understanding this behavior, we can predict and enhance material performance in demanding applications.

Using advanced tools, such as transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD), and x-ray diffraction (XRD), at the Institute for Advanced Materials and Manufacturing (IAMM) at the University of Tennessee, Knoxville, and the Spallation Neutron Source at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory, we conducted an in-depth analysis of the microstructural mechanisms behind fatigue in HEAs. We observed that HEAs exhibit unique deformation and failure modes compared to traditional alloys. Our data show that HEAs can maintain structural integrity under conditions that would typically cause traditional alloys to fail, showcasing a promising pathway toward creating more resilient materials.

Broader Impacts

The broader impact of our work extends beyond the immediate scientific community. The findings offer valuable insights for industries reliant on durable materials, from aerospace to biomedical engineering, and provide a strong foundation for future innovations in alloy design. This project has also opened new educational pathways and opportunities for the next generation of scientists and engineers.

Our project actively involved students in hands-on research, allowing them to conduct experiments with cutting-edge characterization equipment and to apply machine-learning techniques in alloy design. This experiential learning approach fosters essential technical skills and critical thinking among young researchers, equipping them with the competencies needed to advance materials science. Additionally, we created educational activities for K-12 students, introducing concepts of alloy design and materials behavior to a broader, younger audience. Through demonstrations and interactive learning, students gained a glimpse into materials science and engineering, fostering early interest in STEM fields.

Furthermore, our collaborations with senior design classes integrated machine-learning into alloy design, creating a cross-disciplinary approach that highlights the role of data science in modern engineering. This component has not only advanced our research but has also introduced students to the transformative potential of machine learning in scientific-research and industrial applications.

Conclusion

The insights gained from this project contribute to a foundational understanding of high-entropy alloys and their fatigue behavior, positioning these materials as viable candidates for applications demanding high durability. By combining advanced materials characterization with innovative educational outreach, this project not only advances the frontiers of materials science but also cultivates a well-prepared, STEM-focused workforce. The findings underscore the promise of HEAs in enabling more resilient, efficient, and sustainable technologies for the future.

 


Last Modified: 11/28/2024
Modified by: Peter K Liaw
